subject: Re: [junit] How to Test Private Methods Inside a Class
msgSnippet: ... I m not sure if it s the easiest and fastest way...  Making it protected means that your test class (or a class it uses) needs to extend that class. I
messageBody:
On 7/24/06, Andreas Guther <Andreas.Guther@...> wrote:
>
> The question should be also, why is the method private? The most
> obvious reason I can think of is to hide the method from a client class.
> If I want to test a method that is private, I usually decide to make it
> protected. That is the easiest and fastest way.


I'm not sure if it's the easiest and fastest way... Making it protected
means that your test class (or a class it uses) needs to extend that class.

I still think that package protected gives you the best of both worlds: the
method can be used from any class as long as it belongs to the same package,
so the coupling is minimal.

--
Cédric
